EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Â¿Living DocumentÂ¿ Approach To Regulatory Compliance

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP), CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5, the Federal EPA Risk Management Plan, 40 CFR, Part 68, the California Process Safety Management Program, CCR Title 8, Section 5189, and Federal Process Safety Management Program, 29 CFR, Part 1910.119, as enforced by the local Certified Unified Program Agency, Federal EPA, Cal-OSHA, and Federal OSHA.  

This program is intended to be a Â¿living document.Â¿  As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, J. Milicic & Son has chosen to use the software package, PSM WriterÂ©, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc.  This software will assist us with compliance and provide a more efficient method to manage our CalARP and RMP-PSM program elements and keep them up to date.

1.1	J. MILICIC & SON, RISK & PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that J. Milicic & Son has updated their unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program.  The program is in compliance with CaliforniaÂ¿s Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements.  At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68, and California OSHAÂ¿s Â¿Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous MaterialsÂ¿ standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189, Â¿Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials,Â¿ and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119).  This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities:

Process Name	Process Chemical(s)	Process Quantity (lbs)
Ammonia Refrigeration	Anhydrous Ammoni

a	35,000

Our program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.

J. Milicic & Son has an exemplary safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety.  We have: (1) prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well; (2) reorganized the program so that it meshes more closely with general J. Milicic & Son business practices; and (3) reviewed plan documentation forms and responsibilities.  The unified Risk & Process Safety Management Plan sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees protect themselves and our neighbors.

1.2	PROCESS DESCRIPTIONS

J. Milicic operates a commercial cold storage for table grapes.  The ammonia system provides refrigerating capacity five (5) precool rooms, five (5) storage rooms, and a hallway. 

The systems operate as follows. High pressure liquid from our main receivers is piped to each cold room, where it passes through a liquid control valve into low temperature & pressure accumulator vessels. From the accumulators, cold liquid ammonia is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature & pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessel. The ammonia vapor is returned from the accumulator vessels through a suction return line to our engine room, where it passes through the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressor is sent to the water cooled condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to our receiver.

The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the co

mpressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and safety relief valves which vent ammonia gas to the adsorption tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point.  Lastly, an emergency Â¿dump boxÂ¿ contains switches and valves to turn off equipment and vent ammonia if necessary. 

The ammonia system at our facility consists of vessels which are interconnected, or which are co-located such that a release of ammonia could impact the ability to operate vessels that are not directly connected. Therefore, we are treating the system as a single process.

1.3	GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE & CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

1.3.1	GENERAL.

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of any one of the regulated chemicals in annual safety meetings.  These employees are made aware of the potential risks of the process chemicals involved.  During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

J. Milicic & Son has also conducted an off-site impact analysis of worst-case and alternate-case release scenarios for each process.  These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release.  The results of the analyses are reported in the body of the program.

1.3.2	ANHYDROUS AMMONIA.

The ammonia refrigeration process at the J. Milicic & Son facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner.  Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia.  In addition, the system/process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that w

e use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity review of our ammonia equipment.

1.4	FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

J. Milicic & Son has had no accidental releases within the last five (5) years. 

1.5	EMERGENCY ACTION PLAN

This facilityÂ¿s emergency response program is based on the Cal/OSHA requirements for Emergency Action Plans (in California CCR Title 8, Section 3220, Â¿Emergency Action Plans.Â¿  Federally, Title 29 CFR 1910.38 and 1910.119), HAZWOPER (standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5192, Â¿Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response,Â¿ and Title 29 CFR 1910.120). 

Strategically, we will respond Â¿minimallyÂ¿ to a release.  Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. Select J. Milicic & Son employees have been trained as First Responders Operations (as defined by the HAZWOPER regulation).  Those trained individuals will participate in a response event using only Â¿defensiveÂ¿ actions that can be safety completed with little or no personal protective equipment.   All offensive response activities would be done in coordination with the Kern County Environmental Health Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team.
Every year at the beginning of the season we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release. 

1.6	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Our company has an outstanding safety record, one that we are quite proud of.  Many policies and procedures have been implemented to promote overall plant, worker and public safety.  Nevertheless, J. Milicic & Son continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.  The overhaul of this Risk & Process Safety Management Program has been the primary recent improvement, and implementation of the program is our plan for improved safety in the near future.

The Risk & Process Safety Management Program has been written so that program elements are ali

gned with J. Milicic & Son business practices rather than the order presented in the law.  Thus, Safe Operating Procedures are grouped together for the benefit of our system operator.  Safe Operating Policies are grouped together so that appropriate office staff may administer them.  The Emergency Action Plan is now separated out and distributed widely through the plant for easy reference.  

The Risk & Process Safety Management Program documentation forms and company policy forms pertaining to employee, contractor, and community safety have been carefully reviewed so as to prevent unnecessary complexity and redundancy.  Our operators have assisted in the writing of Standard Operating Procedures, and they are presented in a format that is easy to use.  

For the future, J. Milicic & Son now thinks of the Risk & Process Safety Management Program as a Â¿living documentÂ¿.  It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for J. Milicic & Son employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement.  Through the Risk & Process Safety Management Program J. Milicic & Son will continue to maintain overall plant, worker and public safety.
